awd_titl_txt: GEM: Magnetotail Reconnection Signatures at Lunar Orbit
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's magnetic field encloses it in a protective cocoon, called the magnetosphere, deflecting most of the solar wind around it. The solar wind is a stream of charged particles and magnetic fields blowing outward from the Sun, which varies in intensity with solar activity. Because of its interaction with the solar wind, the magnetosphere is compressed on the dayside and extended in a long "magnetotail" on the nightside. The stretched magnetotail field lines store energy extracted from the solar wind. This energy is released by a process called magnetic reconnection, the subject of the present study, during which magnetic energy is converted into plasma flows as well as heating and energization of plasmas within the Earth's magnetosphere. Magnetic reconnection occurs at two locations:  one in the near-tail at a distance of 15-30 Earth radii and the other in the distant tail at 100-200 Earth radii. The near-Earth reconnection is explosive, creating high-energy charged particles that are responsible for the dynamic auroras in the upper atmosphere but also for damage to Earth-orbiting satellites. Near-Earth reconnection is largely associated with space weather events called magnetic storms and substorms. In contrast, the distant tail reconnection (about which much less is known) is envisioned to be steadier. It is not understood how the two reconnection sites interact. Of major importance for the present study, fast plasma flows are produced moving both Earthward and tailward from each of these reconnection sites. A satellite at lunar orbit (~60 Earth radii) between the two sites has the important advantage of being able to detect tailward flows from the near-Earth site, and earthward flows from the distant tail site. Thus the connection between the two, and the impact on magnetotail conditions of each, can be investigated from the same mid-tail vantage point. New insights into magnetic reconnection from the suggested study are valuable for research in planetary magnetospheres, as well as astrophysical and laboratory plasmas. The suggested work will provide important training for graduate students. It also includes public outreach and educational activities.

To accomplish the goals described above, the proposers will analyze observations from the Artemus (Acceleration, Reconnection, Turbulence, and Electrodynamics of the Moon's Interaction with the Sun) satellites in lunar orbit at ~60 Earth radii using case and statistical studies to investigate the occurrence rates of reconnection outflows from both near- and distant-tail reconnection sites, their variations over a range of space weather conditions (quiescent to magnetic storming), the timing between them (i.e., which site activates first), as well as consequences to the mid-tail space environment, such as transient electric field enhancements, changes in the magnetic field geometry, and enhancements in high-energy particle fluxes.

por.por_cntn:
A magnetotail of a magnetic planet magnetosphere is formed by solar wind drag of the dipole magnetic field on the planet's night side. The Earth's magnetotail extends for a hundred or even a couple of hundreds Earth's radii (RE). The near-equatorial magnetotail is populated by hot and rarefied plasma, so called plasma sheet. A region of strong magnetic field gradient, or, the same, strong electric current called ``current sheet'' is located inside the plasma sheet in the equatorial magnetotail. Being a narrow boundary between the magnetotail lobes that contain the magnetic field of opposite polarity, the current sheet is highly dynamic and becomes unstable when the current density in it exceeds a critical value. The processes of current sheet instability lead to explosive conversion of the magnetic energy into the kinetic and thermal energies of the plasma. This energy conversion process is known as ``magnetic reconnection''. Magnetic reconnection in the magntotail is responsible for generation of the fast plasma flows, known as ``bursty bulk flows'' (BBFs), that collapse towards the quasi-dipole magnetic field in the nightside inner magnetosphere. The deposited energy goes to acceleration of charged particles () electrons and ions) that precipitate into the ionosphere and upper atmosphere and produce a spectacular aurora in auroral rings around north and south magnetic poles. The energized particles also intrude to the equatorial inner magnetosphere, where they energized up to relativistic energies. The relativistic electrons, know as ``killer electrons'' may significantly damage electronics of satellites at geosynchronous and cis-synchronous orbits. Therefore, it is important to understand physics of magnetic reconnection in the magntotail its consequences. 
In this project we used observations from two ARTEMIS satellites orbiting around the Moon. Lunar orbit crosses the Earth's magnetotail at radial distance of 60 RE. The ARTEMIS duo crosses the magnetotail with the Moon during approximately 4 days every month.  When reconnection happens earthward of lunar orbit, the ARTEMIS observe fast plasma flow and magnetic flux transport directed from the Earth anti-sunward. When reconnection happens tailward of the lunar orbit, ARTEMIS may observe earthward plasma flow and energetic particle burst. We collected these data to address the following questions: i) how often reconnection occur earthward and tailward of lunar orbit? ii)  what are properties of magnetic field and plasma in earthward and tailward reconnection outflows? iii) what is a magnetic configuration of the magnetotail current sheet at lunar orbit? Our main results are 

I. Our statistical studies revealed the characteristic patterns in plasma flows in the lunar-distant magnetotail. We found that earthward and tailward fast flows are equaly probale at lunar orbit, but whereas the tailward flows carry a significant amount of the magnetic flux, the earthward flows are typically field aligned.

II. Using the observed typical ion temperature and density and assuming pressure equilibrium, we found that the ion population observed within tailward reconnection ejecta at lunar distances was originated in the near-Earth plasma sheet at distances X=-25 to -30 RE.  

III. We found that the magnetotail current sheet at lunar distances is often in the quasi-force-free state.

Our results are published in a set of scientific papers in Journal of Geophysical Research - Space Physics (4 papers) and Geophysical Research Letters (1 letter).
